content:
Outbox only exists if you send mail "later" (ctrl+shift+Enter) as opposed to send now (ctrl+Enter) it should usually be empty and resides exclusively in the local folders account, although I did see a bug about moving that to one per email account, but I do not think that has been implemented as yet.

However if something has deleted it, sending an email later will recreate it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
What is your idea of an "Alias" I see it used as a term here all the time, but there is not actually a "thing" called an alias in email, so like most old wives tales. Definitions differ.

Are you using the Microsoft one https://support.microsoft.com/en-au/office/add-or-remove-an-email-alias-in-outlook-com-459b1989-356d-40fa-a689-8f285b13f1f2

Notice they say it is an email address. what they do not say, is that if you use a mail client to send email for one of these "alias" addresses that they will strip the information inserted by the mail client and replace it with that of the primary registered alias as the message goes through their mail servers.

You are far netter off using it as a real email address and using the appropriate sign in information for that address in the SMTP as that avoids the whole stripping of name and email address data. I will point out that they do not do this is you use their web page interface, only mail clients.


So you need to have an outgoing server(SMTP) entry in account settings for each and every one of these ALIAS addresses and not use them as an Alias as such.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird has no grammar checker or autocorrect. So I guess you will need to use the shift key.

There are a number of grammar type addons. One of them may offer the items you seek https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/search/?q=grammar&appver=&platform=
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Press and hold the CTRL key on your computer keyboard. Click on the emails you want to delete one after the other to select them. Press the delete key. Or click on the first in the list, hold the shift key click on the last to select everything between the clicks. Or click into the list and select Ctrl+A to select everything in the list.

With care you can fine tune a select all or select between by changing to the Ctrl key and clicking a selected item to deselect it. Clicking again will re-select

This is not really a Thunderbird "function" as the shortcuts have existed in windows since at least version 3, about 1985.

I am basing this on using the list or what is now the table view to manage mail as that is how I use it, but a quick check in the newer card view offers the same functionality so you should get the same result whichever you use.
creator: MattAuSupport
